 BOLIVIA - POWER SECTOR REFORM TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROJECT TECHNICAL ANNEX - THE PROJECT SECTION A: Detailed Project Description 1. Background . The Bolivian Government is making extensive use of both internationally- recruited and domestic consultants and advisors in the preparation and implementation of its re- form and capitalization programs in the various sectors. The main reform milestones achieved so far have been related to the preparation and promulgation of the legal regulatory framework of the power sector, and much of the assistance received to date has been financed from various sources. The Electricity Law enacted on December 21, 1994, was prepared during May 1993 through December 1994, with the Energy Sector Management Assistance Program (ESMAP) and the International Development Agency (IDA) assistance. The elaboration of key regulations and the preparation of the generation assets of Empresa Nacional de Electricidad (ENDE) for capitali- zation were supported by a Japanese Grant Facility, by a small Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) grant, and by some of the proceeds of Cr. 2647-BO. The preparation of the key tasks of the proposed operation is being supported by PPF 900-00-BO (MOP, Para. 11). The proposed operation will fund the additional technical assistance required by the Secretary of Energy and Ministry of Capitalization to carry out key reform transition activities and complete the reform and capitalization programs. 2. Project Components. The overall TA has been organized into four parts to support: (A) the operations of the reform implementation unit - referred to as the Technical Group - and the establishment of the regulatory system for the power sector; (B) the implementation of re- form transition activities; (C) the completion of the restructuring of the Government of Bolivia (GOB)-owned utilities; and (D) the completion of privatization or divestment from GOB-owned utilities. The following section provides the detailed descriptions of each project component. Part A: Operations of the Technical Group and strengthening the regulatory system for the power sector 1) Technical Group: Supporting the Technical Group by means of providing the re- sources necessary for the operations thereof, including staff and specialized consult- ant services. 2) Strengthening of the Regulatory system: Assessment of the suitability of current regulations to the Power Law (and if warranted, the pertinent provisions of the regulations to the Sistema de Regulacion Sectorial (SIRESE) and Capitalization Laws) in light of the experience gained in the operation of the NIS up to September 30, 1996 and, if so required by the assessment, putting into effect, through the ap- propriate channels, amendments to such regulations, particularly on the following subjects: pricing, dispatch, quality of service, penalties, rights of way, terms and conditions for concessions and licenses and environmental aspects.
 2 Part B: Transition requirements 1) Pricing studies: Execution of one or more pricing studies: a) to review or determine, as required, the economic costs of: (i) generation in the NIS (National Interconnected System); (ii) distribution in the NIS; and (iii) of each IS (Isolated System) whose generation and distribution functions could be integrated in the future; b) to determine the costs of the economically adapted transmission system and subtransmission including the ancillary system reserve and reliability costs; c) to determine the economic costs of power supply at the retail distribution level; and d) to determine a policy to provide life-line subsidies consisting with the regional environs and causing a minimal impact to market price signals. 2) Wholesale power market: Putting in place phase I (the first of 2 phases) of the crea- tion of the National Load Dispatch Committee (NLDC), the entity charged, pursuant to the provisions of the Power Sector Law with implementing a wholesale power market. Such Phase 1, will include the upgrading of the current regional national load dispatch and transmission system to enable the prompt adaptation of the present system to operate under the open access conditions and effective commercial prac- tices, the detailed design of phase 2 and the following activities: a) adaptation of the existing optimization and commercial settlement software and hardware of ENDE's Centro de Despacho de Carga (LDC); b) determination of the organization (including regulations such as those for pro-. cedural and administrative operation), staffing and operating budget, all for the LDC and NLDC for both phases I and 2; c) as a complement to Part A2 of the project, reviewing, and as required, making recommendations for refining of the new dispatch rules, pricing and clearing house functions of the NLDC in view of the experience gained in the first months of operation of NIS and in line with the pertinent provisions of the Power Sector Law; d) training of ENDE's personnel assigned to the LDC on load dispatch opera- tional activities. e) determination of specifications for the procurement of metering and commu- nications equipment to reinforce the existing dispatch facilities, and for assist- ing in international competitive bidding processes; and f) designing in detail the configuration of the NLDC to be implemented under phase 2, including: (i) determination of specifications for hardware and addi- tional metering and communication systems and equipment therefor to be procured under such phase 2; and (ii) preparation of terms of reference and action plans for, and estimated costs of, implementation of phase 2.
 3 3) Environmental Assessment (EA): Carrying out the second and final phase of the en- vironmental assessment of the power sector under the terms of reference prepared during the first phase (carried out under terms of reference dated August 19, 1994) and which include the following principal tasks: a) the carrying out of (i) environmental audits and of those ENDE-owned diesel fired plants designated for capitalization and not visited during the aforesaid first phase (i.e. plants below 4 MW); and (ii) surveys and measurements re- quired to develop detailed action plans to mitigate environmental impacts identified during first phase and relating to asbestos, diesel-oil and noise con- tamination by the plants designated for capitalization; b) the carrying out of audits of the specific environmental and social issues asso- ciated with the existing transmission facilities of the NIS and preparation of action plans to mitigate any adverse environmental impact revealed by each of said audits in a manner consistent with the prevailing Borrower's environ- mental legislation; c) a review of the most recent environmental policy activities of both the power sector and the Borrower's Ministry of Sustainable Development and Environ- ment (MOSD), development of recommendations for amendments to specific items of draft regulations, and assessment of the effectiveness of the existing and proposed framework for the implementation and enforcement of the Bor- rower's environmental policy and legislation in the power sector; and d) a progress report on the mitigation work that was identified during the afore- said first phase for the facilities of each of the three ENDE's capitalized gen- erating companies, including a brief assessment of the obligations of said capitalized generating companies to carry out said works under existing legis- lation, environmental regulations and terms of their generation licenses. 4) Strengthening of the National Secretariat of Energy (NSE): Development of key functions to enable NSE to coordinate and monitor the power sector policy objec- tives, balance of energy supply and demand, and strategic energy mix, in urban and rural areas, to promote new direct private investment in the power sector and to en- sure the dissemination of sectoral statistics, including the following activities: a) development of a power sector strategic analysis capability to monitor and adapt the sectoral policy objectives to evolving circumstances in a manner consistent with the national energy strategy and legal framework, by means, inter-alia, of: (i) the establishment and start-up operations of an unit charged with the responsibility of developing power sector policy and promoting pri- vate investment in the sector; (ii) the assessment of staff and other human re- sources requirements for said unit as well as its operational physical require- ments including computer hardware and software, database, and communica- tion tools therefor; and (iii) executing, through such unit of the activities un- der (b) through (e) below;
 4 b) (i) definition of the role of the public sector in ensuring the supply of electric- ity in a privatized power sector, including public sector action regarding the response of power utilities and private sector enterprises; (ii) execution of the first indicative least cost investment plan for the power sector (with the assis- tance of ENDE's LDC or NLDC referred to in Part B. 2 of the Project, as the case may be) and of the procedures for harmonizing the national energy strat- egy with the future indicative expansions plan(s) for the power sector; and (iii) overviewing, and if necessary coordinating, the preparation of indicative least cost investment plan(s) for the sector to promote private investment in new power projects, including the planning criteria for addressing risk-associated and environmental issues; c) establishment of: (i) a sectoral database and mechanisms to provide informa- tion to developers regarding the recommendations resulting from the aforesaid indicative expansion plan(s) and (ii) procedures for involving users and other interested parties in decisions regarding power sector projects; d) addressing development, social and environmental issues in connection with power supply in matters such as power coverage extensions policies, rural electrification and service provision to isolated communities; e) securing sufficient funding for, and defining the scope for coordinating and monitoring the execution of, specific power projects (including pre-feasibility and feasibility studies) to support the indicative expansion plan(s) for the sector, all in the framework of the Borrower's energy policy; and f) training for staff under the leadership of the unit referred to in para. 4)a)(i) above, and acquisition and utilization of hardware and software for such unit and laboratory equipment for the environmental section of the power sector. 5) Rural areas: Execution of one or more studies in the following areas in order to de- sign a strategy to assure the energy development of smaller cities and rural areas, and to enable the Borrower to carry out the strategy so designed: a) determination of options for financially sustainable rural energy development mechanisms, particularly for the Beni region; b) establishment of economic and technical criteria for: (i) selecting and evaluat- ing options and geographic areas for rural energy development; (ii) beneficiary assessment; (iii) cost recovery and electricity pricing for both regulated and unregulated consumers; (iv) rational and transparent subsidization criteria for capital investment cost; and (v) evaluation of the scope for using non- conventional local energy sources for electricity generation in areas where grid extension is not economically justified; and
 5 c) identification and evaluation of at least two viable projects for implementation during the next five years in the framework of the Borrower's energy policy. Part C: Restructuring the power utilities currently owned or controlled by the Borrower or agencies thereof Assisting NSE and the Ministry of Capitalization (MOC) in evaluating options and deter- mining specific action plans to instill commercial and financial viability to ENDE, the existing dis- tribution companies in Sucre and Potosi in which ENDE has an equity interest, and each utility operating an IS, all through completion of their respective ongoing restructuring; and additionally, implementation of institutional, management and financial restructuring, including: 1) diagnosing the relevant institutional, financial and commercial issues involved; and car- rying out financial, technical and legal studies to assess the likely market value of the net-worth of each ENDE and IS business unit and cost center; and 2) determining preliminary capitalization, and/or privatization and/or contracted manage- ment strategies, including or not the prior creation of a MEC, and implementation of improvement action plans which may include management contracts with utility op- erations. Part D: Capitalization and Privatization I) Preparation, pursuant to the provisions of the Capitalization Law or the Privatization Law, as the case may be, of divestment options based on the results of the carrying out of Part C of the Project; and 2) Execution of the selected divestment option for each enterprise, including: a) preparation of suitable investments prospectus or information memoranda; b) execution of promotion investment seminars and workshops to attract poten- tial investors; c) determination of pre-qualification criteria, bidding procedures and of the re- quired legal documents, including bidding documents; d) assistance in bid analysis and evaluation and award recommendations; e) assistance in contract drafting and negotiations; and f) establishment of procedures for monitoring contract performance. SECTION B: Project Administration and Implementation Project Implementation 3. Responsibility for implementing all components of the project relating to the capitalization programs lies with the MOC (Ministry of Capitalization) through its NSC (National Secretariat of Capitalization). Likewise the implementation responsibility for all components relating to sec- tor policy matters and institutional strengthening of the NSE (National Secretariat of Energy), environmental sector issues, and rural energy development lies with the MOED (Ministry of Eco-
 6 nomic Development) through its National Sub-Secretary of Energy (NSsE) under the NSE. The heads of the NSC and NSsE, are experienced professionals with technical and management expe- rience in the private and public sectors. Those eventual matters of the reform and capitalization programs affecting sectoral or cross-sectoral policies and or strategies, will be dealt through CODENA (National Development Council--Consejo de Desarrollo Nacional) chaired by the President of Bolivia and conformed by the principal sectoral Ministers. However, since the legal and regulatory frameworks for the power sector have already been promulgated and the genera- tion assets of the sector have already been capitalized, it is not envisaged that there would be an active interaction with CODENA. The specific responsibilities for carrying out the various parts of the project are: * MOC: Parts Al, B1, B2, C, and D * MOED: Parts A2, B3, B4, and B5 * ENDE: will assist the above agencies in carrying out all Parts of the project, par- ticularly Parts BI, B2 and B3. 4. The TG, which will have the technical coordination responsibility under the project, will coordinate the definition of tasks, preparation of Terms of Reference (TOR) and overseeing the work of consultants, will assist the NSC and the NSsE in the implementation and reporting as- pects of the project. ENDE-T will be the local counterpart in the activities oriented to put in place the national dispatch and operation of the wholesale power market (Part B2 of the project). Project Administration and Procurement matters will be dealt with by the respective project units of each Ministry: the PU (Procurement unit) under the NSC of the MOC and the PEU (Project Executing Unit) under the NSE of the MOED. 5. The TG was established by means of the Resolucion Ministerial No. 018/94, of December 13, 1994, of the MOC and Resolucion Bisecretarial No. 01/94 of December 14, 1994, of the NSE and NSC. In December 1994, the TG was given a wide mandate to implement the reforms stipulated in the Capitalization and Electricity Laws in coordination with line Ministries. It con- sists of a team of five full-time senior professionals with diverse expertise in the technical, regula- tory, financial and legal aspects of the power sector. With the preparation and lobbying support for the promulgation of the Electricity Law, and the implementation of the Capitalization of ENDE-G, the TG has already established a credible track record in the coordination of highly specialized TA to carry out complex sensitive tasks with very tight deadlines. It is expected that the first regulators of the sector will come from the ranks of the TG because of the valuable expe- rience gained during the reform programs. ENDE-T is the National Utility holding the assets of the National Interconnected System (NIS) -Transmission, Dispatch and of the Isolated Systems which will be privatized or divested during project implementation. ENDE-T has retained the key members of ENDE's management, operations, and project management teams, to ensure the prompt implementation and full debugging of the wholesale power market which is a pre-requisite for the capitalization of its transmission assets. 6. The PU was setup in July 1994 to deal with the large number of consulting contracts re- lated to the capitalization and reform process of all productive sectors including power and being financed under Cr.2647-BO (Regulatory Reform and Capitalization Technical Assistance Project).
 7 The PEU in the NSE was created by MOED's Ministerial Resolution of March 28, 1995 to exe- cute specific components of Credit 2762-BO (Hydrocarbon Sector Reform and Capitalization Technical Assistance Project). The PU which has gained substantial experience since its creation in contracting services according to the procurement guidelines of multilateral agencies, may as- sist the PEU as the latter builds up its own experience. Since the formal responsibilities of the PU cover the scope and objectives of the project no special Resolutions are required from the MOC to establish the PU' s responsibilities under the project. However, a Resolution from the MOED will be required to formalize the PEU's responsibilities under the project. The Project Implemen- tation Organization Chart is shown in Figure 1. The agreed Action Plan, Time Table. and Monitoring indicators shown in Annex 1 highlight the key aspects of project implementation. Schedule B of the MOP shows the procurement methods and the disbursement arrangements. 7. Project monitoring will involve both a control of technical assistance output through prog- ress reports and review meetings with consultants, and a control of timely implementation actions by the MOC and MOED with the assistance of the TG. The outputs of the project are summa- rized in the Action Plan and Project Performance matrix (Annex 1). The recipients of technical assistance will be the institutions involved in sectoral reforms, namely the MOC, MOED, NSE, the Ministry of Sustainable Development and Environment (MOSDE), the SE, ENDE, NLDC, and the Government-owned smaller utilities. 8. IDA staff will hold a project launch workshop shortly after loan signing to review startup action plans and project administration and reporting requirements. The project will be super- vised by IDA staff through receipt and review of the Annual Implementation Programs, monitor- ing of Semi-Annual Implementation Reports and the program of supervision missions indicated in Annex 7. A midterm review of the project to assess progress of major reforms and institutional buildup pursued under the project and to determine the need for adjustments will be held during the first quarter of CY97. Inputs needed to supervise the project are estimated to total about 23 staff-weeks during FY 95 and 96. Supervision will require the involvement of specialists in envi- ronment, power sector regulation, energy economics, power pricing, power dispatch, and privati- zation. Project Preparation Status 9. Except for Parts B2 and D, the TORs to carry out all project components are ready. De- tail TORs for Part B2 which require a prior on-going diagnostic study are scheduled to be ready by end- 1995. While the final TOR for Part D will be prepared during the implementation of Part C, the preliminary scope and TORs for Part D were prepared using the vast experience gained by the TG in the capitalization of ENDE-Generation and in the privatization of the Distribution Util- ity of Cochabamba, ELFEC. Bidding for the most urgent parts of the project will start as soon as final clearance is received from the respective Minister's office flagging, while still required, the processing status of the supporting IDA Credit.

Prior review will be mandatory for all computer hardware and software contracts, and for those contracts for other goods equal to or exceeding US$25,000 equivalent. Contracts for other goods will be subject to IDA post review. Submission of full documentation will be required for all contracts subject to prior review promptly after their signing and prior to delivery to IDA of the first appli- cation for withdrawal of funds from the Credit Account. Disbursements may be made against Statement of Expenditures (SOE's) for the following ex- penditures: (a) contracts for goods other than computer hardware and software valued at US$5,000 equivalent or less; (b) contracts with firms for services including consultants and training for US$60,000 equivalent or less and contracts valued at US$30,000 or less per individual to the extend that such consultant's contracts are not subject to prior review (para. 13). As applicable, the supporting documents for SOE's will be retained by MOC and will be available for review by supervision missions upon re- quest. All other requests for disbursements will require full documentation.

Records and Auditing: Records and auditing will be the responsibility of each unit, the PU and the PEU, which will establish separate accounts for each component and will monitor all expendi- tures financed by this project. Project Accounts, the two Special Accounts and Statements of Ex- penditures will be audited each year by independent auditors satisfactory to IDA and whose services ,will be financed under the proposed IDA Credit, and copies of the audit reports will be submitted to the GOB and IDA within four months after the end of the fiscal year. In addition to financial auditing, the PE and the PEU, under the coordination of the TG, will prepare separate full progress reports and submit them to the GOB and IDA every six months within the fourth week following the end of each semester. Each report will detail all project and related activities, report on the progress in relation to agreed schedules and project milestones, and identify any problems which may have been encountered and which could adversely affect the overall impact of the project. Detailed reporting requirements will be established during the first supervision mission. These auditing and reporting requirements were confirmed during negotiations.

The Bolivian electricity supply industry (ESI) is relatively small with a total installed capacity of 783 MW, total generation in 1994 of 2879.2 GWh and total electricity sales (excluding auto producers) in 1994 of some 2260 GWh. Approximately 64% of the population is served by electricity and the annual per capita consumption is some 320 kWh. 2. The generating capacity in Bolivia comprises 306 MW of hydro (both run of the river and reservoir) and 477 MW of thermal (both gas and diesel fired). In 1994, 48% of total generation in Bolivia came from hydro stations and 52% from thermal stations. Bolivia has extensive energy resources for power generation in the form of hydroelectric potential in the Andean mountain region and natural gas reserves which are concentrated in the south-eastern regions of the country. 3 The ESI is divided into an interconnected system (the "National Interconnected System or "NIS") and a number of Isolated Systems. The NIS covers the principal cities of Bolivia including La Paz, Cochabamba, Santa Cruz, Oruro, Sucre and Potosi, which are interconnected by a network of 69, 115 and 230 kV transmission lines. The Isolated Systems cover Tarija, Villamontes, Yacuiba, Trinidad, Cobija and less populated rural areas. 4. The Bolivian ESI is made up of both vertically integrated and separated utilities with a mixture of private and public ownership, including a number of cooperative distribution companies. Before the capitalization of ENDE-G in August 1995 (Annex 4, para. 7) generation in Bolivia was dominated by ENDE, the state owned utility (with an installed capacity of 495.1 MW), and COBEE, a private sector company (with an installed capacity of 142.2 MW). other public generation and autoproduction made up the remainder. Since the 1960s unlike most unreformed power sectors in Latin America, the power sector in Bolivia has been profitable. The sector has been operated around the 9% rate of return on the legal rate base (based on revalued assets for public utilities, and on historical dollar values for private utilities) allowed by the Electricity Code of 1968. Recent pricing studies indicate that while the price levels of Generation are in line with economic costs those for transmission and distribution need a pricing structure analysis to reflect the consumption load profile of consumers, and weed-out the effect of sunk costs and obsolescence of some parts of the transmission assets. 8. A full economic impact and affordability analysis resulting from the price adjustment to reflect full economic costs mandated by the new Electricity Law, was carried out in February 1994 by London Economics (Consultant - UK). The results indicate that the adjustments are not likely to have material impacts on power demand as a whole nor on the life-line consumers who by in large are already paying prices close to economic costs. The greater but manageable adjustment required will mainly affect medium size low voltage consumers (domestic and commercial) which do not have critical affordability issues. 9. The relatively small overall price adjustment that is expected to be required is not likely to alter the power demand profile in any material way. Fuel substitution away from power is also unlikely because of the forthcoming deregulation of fuel prices that would result from the reform of the hydrocarbon sector slated for 1996. ESMAP expects to complete an economic impact analysis of the expected deregulation of fuel prices during the first quarter of CY 1996.

 ANNEX 3 1 of 6 ANNEX 3: THE NEW LEGAL AND REGULATORY FRAMEWORK AND INDUSTRY STRUCTURE The Electricity Law and New Industry Structure 1. The Electricity Law, Law No. 1604 of 21 December 1994 replaces the 'Electricity Code' enacted in 1968 and establishes new principles governing concessions, licenses, tariffs, rights of wav, penalties, etc. This section summarizes the key provisions of the law. Regulations relating to the electricity sector pursuant to the Electricity Law (para. 2.5) were enacted in June 1995. Principles of the Law 2. The Electricity Law sets out the following principles for the electricity industry: * efficiency: the correct and optimal allocation and utilization of resources in the supply of electricity at minimum cost, * transparency: transparency in the regulatory system established in the SIRESE and Electricity laws, * quality: compliance with the technical requirements to be established in the Regulations. - continuity: a continuous electricity supply without unjustified interruptions; - adaptability: the use of modern technology and administrative systems to promote quality and efficiency; and * neutrality: the impartial treatment of all electricity companies and consumers. New Industry Structure 3. The Law provides for the introduction (subject to the law) of a freely competitive electricity market and the dissagregation of the electricity industry in the NIS into separate generation, transmission, distribution and dispatch activities. The Isolated Systems may be vertically integrated. A company in the NIS may only be engaged in one of generation, transmission and distribution activities. 4. The Law restricts the common ownership of generation, transmission and distribution. Generation or distribution companies (or certain related entities) may not own any shares in, or exercise management control of, a transmission company and transmission companies (or certain related entities) may not own shares in, or exercise management control of, a generation or distribution company. Similarly, a generation company (or certain related entities) may not own any shares in, or exercise management control of, a distribution company and a distribution company mav not own anv shares in, or exercise management control of, a generation company. 5. Distributors connected to the NIS are not allowed to own, directly or indirectly, any generating capacity, likewise generators are not allowed to own shares in distribution companies. 6. The law also contains provisions relating to the relative size of generation companies and stipulates that a generation company (or certain related entities) may not oun, directly or indirectly, more than 35% of the installed capacity in the NIS (excluding capacity utilized for
 ANNEX 3 2 of 6 electricity exports). However, the Superintendency of Electricity ("SE") can authorize temporary exceptions to this limit. 7. All generators in the NIS will be subject to dispatch by the Comite Nacional de Despacho de Carga ("CNDC") and may enter into Electricity Supply Contracts ("ESCs") with other generators, Distributors or Unregulated Consumers. 8. Open access to transmission in the NIS will be available to all electricity companies and Unregulated Consumers. A transmission company may not buy or sell electricity. 9. The CNDC will be responsible for the coordination of generation, transmission and dispatch in the NIS to achieve minimum cost. The CNDC will be formed by a representative of the generation, transmission and distribution companies respectively, a representative of the Unregulated Consumers and a representative of the SE. The dispatch center of the CNDC will be owned by the transmission company owning the Trunk Interconnected System although the SE has the power to order the creation of an independent company to owvn the dispatch center which would be owned by the electricity companies and Unregulated Consumers. The Law provides for the full recovery of the operating costs of dispatch and of managing the commrercial transactions of the wholesale power market. The functions of the CNDC include: - to plan the integrated operation of the NIS with the aim of satisfying demand through secure, liable and minimum cost operation; - to carry out dispatch; to calculate the effective capacity of generators in the NIS; and to calculate node prices in the NIS and present them to the SE for approval. 10. In order to promote a rational utilization of primary resources in Bolivia, the Executive Power may define the minimum participation of hydroelectric capacity in the NIS. Institutional organization 11. Under the Electricity Law the National Secretary of Energy (SNE) will propose general regulations for approval by the Executive Power which will be applied by the SE. The National Secretarv of Energy will also develop an indicative plan (which will be for reference purposes only) i.e. a minimum cost plan for generation and transmission projects (which will include projects proposed by any generators and the National Secretary of Energy), necessary to cover the next ten years increase in electricity demand in the NIS. The SNE will normally update the indicative plan on a yearly basis. 12. The SE will act as the regulator of the electricity industry and will be headed by a Superintendent. In addition to the general powers set out in the SIRESE Law (para. 18) the Superintendent of Electricity will have the specific powers in the Electricity Law to: * protect consumers rights; * ensure that the activities of the electricity industry comply with the antimonopoly and consumer protection provisions of the SIRESE, Electricity and Environmental Laws
 ANNEX 3 3 of 6 and respective Regulations; grant and amend concessions, Licenses and provisional licenses in line with these Regulations; * intervene in utilities which have not complied with the Electricity Law and its Regulations; * apply the tariff and price setting procedures established in the Electricity Law and its Regulations for generation, transmission and distribution and approve and regulate maximum prices and tariffs; * approve international interconnections and the export and import of electricity; supervise the CNDC; and apply penalties. 13. The operations of the SE and a proportionate part of the operating costs of the General Superintendency will be financed by a regulatory levy to be paid by electricity companies which cannot exceed 1 % of their sales revenues before indirect taxes. Their initial capital costs will be co-financed by multilateral and bilateral loans and grants. Concessions and Licenses 14. Under the Electricity Law, Distributors and integrated companies in the Isolated Systems will operate under the terms of public service concessions with a maximum period of 40 years. Generators and Transmitters in the NIS will be authorized to operate by Licenses of indefinite duration. Authority to conduct studies for certain new generation plants or transmission capacity (utilizing natural resources, or public goods or requiring the imposition of rights of way) will require a provisional license (which will provide a preferential right to obtain a License for the project at a later stage). All concessions, Licenses and provisional licenses will be granted by the SE through two alternative procedures being either at the request of interested parties or through public tenders. The applicability of each procedure, the mechanisms for applying for concessions, Licenses and provisional licenses and provisions relating to the termination and revocation of concessions and Licenses are set out in the Electricity Law and Regulations. 15. Distributors, under their concessions will have an obligation to satisfy all demand for electricity in their concession area. To fulfill this obligation the law requires them to enter into Electricity Supply Contracts (ESI) with generators covering a minimum of 80% of their maximum demand for a minimum period of three years. The percentage and the period may be modified by the SE. Prices and Tariffs 16. The Electricity Law and the Regulations provide for the introduction of a new system of pricing and tariffs for the electricity sector based on marginal costs for Generation and Transmission, and on price-cap (RPI - X) incentive regulation for Distribution. Transitional Provisions 17. The Electricity Law contains a number of transitional provisions governing the transition from the existing to the new industry framework. These provisions include the following: * that the dissaggregation of the industry in accordance with the law should be achieved within 18 months;

THE SIRESE LAW AND REGULATORY FRAMEWORK 18. Law No. 1600 of 28 October 1994 has established a new sectoral regulatory system for Bolivia called the "Sistema de Regulaci6n Sectorial" or "SIRESE". This new sectoral regulation covers the telecommunications, electricity, hydrocarbon, transport and water sectors and can be expanded to cover other sectors in the future. 19. The SIRESE has been created as an autonomous entity under the auspices of the Ministry of Economic Development and is based on a two tier structure comprising a General Superintendency and a series of Sectoral Superintendencies. The General Superintendency will oversee the activities of the SIRESE and the Sectoral Superintendencies and will be headed by a Superintendent General who, except during an initial transition period, will hold office for 7 years. Each Sectoral Superintendency will be headed by a Sectoral Superintendent who will hold office, except during an initial transition period, for a period of 5 years. The Superintendent General and Sectoral Superintendents will be independent and are not allowed to have any economic interest in the areas for which they are responsible. 20. Both the General Superintendent and each of the Sectoral Superintendents will be designated by the President of the Republic of Bolivia from among the groups of three candidates proposed by a two thirds majority vote of the Senate. 21. Although each of the new sectoral laws (such as the Electricity Law) will set out specific powers for the Sectoral Superintendents, the SIRESE law sets out a number of general powers including: * promoting competition and efficiency and investigating monopolistic, anti-competitive and discriminatory practices against the public interest; * granting, modifying, renewing and deciding on the expiry or revocation of concessions and licenses under the provisions of the sectoral law; overseeing the carrying out of investment commitments;
 ANNEX 3 5 of 6 * approving and publishing prices and tariffs in accordance with the relevant sectoral laws and supervising their correct application; * applying penalties where provided for in sectoral laws or in concession or license contracts; and * processing complaints and claims by users, regulated companies and the state. 22. Electricity sector companies will have a right to appeal to the Superintendent General against decisions of the Superintendency of Electricity and a further right of appeal to the Supreme Court. 23. The SIRESE law contains a number of anti-monopolistic and competition provisions. These provisions require that, except as provided for in sectoral laws and regulations, companies in the electricity and other regulated sectors must carry out their activities in a manner which promotes free competition and must avoid acts which would impede, restrict or distort it. The law also provides that companies in the electricity and other regulated sectors are prohibited from participating in agreements or arrangements whose purpose or effect is to impede, restrict or distort free competition through price fixing, control of production, markets, sources of supply or investments or other similar activities. In addition, the law includes provisions to combat abusive and anti- competitive commercial practices which are damaging to competitors, clients or users. Mergers of competing companies subject to regulation are prohibited where they would establish, promote or consolidate a dominant market position. Secondary Legislation 24. Detailed provisions implementing the Electricity Law are contained in secondary legislation or Regulations. These were passed by supreme decree and any future revision do not require Congressional approval. 25. The main Regulations which will be implemented pursuant to the Electricity Law cover the following areas: * Prices and Tariffs ('Precios y Tarifas') * Operation ('operacion') * Quality of supply ('Calidad de Suministro') * Infringements and Penalties ('Infracciones y Sanciones') * Concessions and Licenses ('Concesiones y Licencias') * Rights of Way ('Servidumbres') 26. The program has a number of aims, including: * to issue shares representing up to 50% holdings, and to transfer management control of, the six companies to the private sector; * to bring into Bolivia significant amounts of fresh investment capital to fund infrastructure and industrial development in the six sectors; and * to create national pension fund schemes to provide, for the first time, pensions to the entire Bolivian people. This will be structured and regulated by a new pensions law. 3. Under the Capitalization Program each of the enterprises to be Capitalized will first be transformed into a mixed economy corporation (a "S.A.M."), that is a corporation owned partially by state and partially by private interests (being initially workers in the company) since under Bolivian law only a corporation can issue shares. An international tender will then be held to select the investor or group of investors which will subscribe for new shares representing 50% of the share capital of the S.A.M.s. The subscribed capital will be doubled by the issue of the new shares. The subscription moneys will be paid into the S.A.M.s and will be available to fund future investments. The Government will receive no proceeds from the Capitalizations and following the Capitalization, the S.A.M.'s will be converted into S.A.'s signaling the end of the Governments participation as a shareholder in the companies. 4. The work force of the state-owned company from which a S.A.M. is formed will be entitled to subscribe for shares in the S.A.M. up to the amount of their Social Benefits. The remaining shares in the
 ANNEX 4 2 of 4 S.A.M.s will be used to establish a new national pension fund scheme. These shares will be held initially by the Trustee/Custodian, which will be a leading international bank in the provision of trustee and custodian services. In due course, the Bolivian pension funds will wish to achieve liquidity for their shareholdings in the capitalized companies to enable them to diversify their portfolios and satisfy their obligations to pay pensions. It is therefore anticipated that each of the capitalized corporations will be listed in due course on Bolivian and other stock exchanges. 5. As a necessary adjunct to the Capitalization Program, the Government has introduced a new regulatory regime covering the telecommunications, electricity, hydrocarbon, transport and water sectors. The new SIRESE Law No. 1600 of 28 October 1994 which creates a new system of sectoral regulation (the "Sistema de Regulacion Sectorial" or "SIRESE') is described in more detail in Annex 3, para. 18. 6. In parallel with the Capitalization Program, a more traditional privatization program is being implemented covering a variety of smaller state owned enterprises in activities ranging from agriculture and cement to textiles and hotels.  ANNEX 5 1 of2 TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR THE ENVIRONMENTAL AUDIT OF THE POWER SECTOR IN BOLIA (PHASE II) INTRODUCTION Under the proposed Capitalization and Reform of the Power Sector undertaken by the Government of Bolivia the National Electricity Company (ENDE) is to capitalize its assets into the following business units: Gl, G2, G3 and Transmission. To ensure that the proposed reform and ensuing legislation meets sound environmental guidelines, the Government wishes to carry out an Environmental Assessment (EA) of the power sector in two phases. The first phase - an environmental audit of ENDE's generating plant over 4 MW, and a full institutional and legislative review - has been carried out by a Consultant. The environmental audits of the generating plant included hydro-electric and thermal (diesel and gas) plants, and produced a series of action plans to address significant issues of concern which were identified. The institutional study examined whether the institutional and legal structure in place in Bolivia is sufficient to ensure sustainability and effective regulation of environmental objectives after sector reform and the capitalization of ENDE. These TOR relate to Phase 2 of work to be undertaken and reflect the findings of the Phase I study and the progress that has been made in environmental policy and regulation since the completion of that work. ENVIRONMENTAL REQUIREMENTS AND REVIEW OF THE POWER SECTOR Environmental audits completed for this study will comply with all environmental guidance, laws and regulations of Bolivia as well as the World Bank requirements included in the Banks Operational Directive (OD) 4.01 of October 1991 as applicable to environmental category "B" projects; whenever necessary other international standards or guidelines will be used prior agreement within the Government and the Bank. The Consultant will develop a thorough understanding of the power sector of Bolivia. The Consultant will obtain from ENDE information on the existing power generating and transmission system and the expansion needs identified (including the report prepared for Phase I of this study). SCOPE OF WORK: The project comprises the following components: Phase I of the Project identified particular concerns at those diesel fired plants which were visited. Phase II of the project therefore includes environmental audits of those ENDE diesel fired plants not visited during Phase I (i.e. plant below 4 MW). . A detailed evaluation of the specific environmental and social issues associated with the existing Transmission facilities of the main interconnected system. * A review of the most recent environmental policy activities of both the power sector and the Ministry of Sustainable Development and Environment and development of recommendations for amendments to specific items of draft Regulations. In addition, the study will develop a practical and cost-effective framework for the implementation and enforcement of Bolivian environmental policy and legislation. * The carrying out of urgent work on the three G's that was identified during Phase I of the project. The TASKS to be undertaken are described below: Task 1. The Consultant will evaluate specific environmental, safety and social issues associated with any ENDE diesel fired plant under 4 MW which is designated for capitalization (this plant was not subject to audit during Phase I of the project). Task 2. The Consultant will evaluate specific environmental and social issues associated with the existing Transmission facilities of the main interconnected system, and, if needed, provide economic and cost-effective
 ANNEX 5 2 of 2 recommendations with prioritized mitigatory measures, estimated costs and schedules, all in the form of an Annex to be part of the capitalization agreement of ENDE's Transmission system. The study should include, but not be limited to: an assessment of the methods and guidelines used by ENDE in the transmission planning process, the implementation and effectiveness of those methods; an inspection of major sub-stations and other transmission facilities; a review of on-going procedures for the maintenance of transmission facilities (vegetation control, oil changing etc.) and any measures taken to mitigate environmental and social effects. Task 3. There exists a growing body of secondary environmental legislation to both the Electricity and Environment Laws in Bolivia and the Consultant should assess whether, given the institutional structure, the legislation will be effective in environmental regulation of the power sector. The Consultant will work with the Environmental Unit in ENDE and the Regulation Project for the Environment Law in the Ministry of Sustainable Development and Environment. Task 4. This task will involve an assessment of the most appropriate mechanism for the enforcement of environment policy in Bolivia taking into account economic, political, technical and environmental considerations. The work should concentrate on the power sector but consider the implications for environmental regulation of all sectors. Both short term and long term considerations should be examined. The work will focus on permitting, compliance checking and enforcement. Amendments and additions to existing draft regulations will be suggested in order to allocate legal powers and establish the framework which will ensure effective permitting, compliance and enforcement in the regulatory system. The Consultant will collaborate with the relevant personnel in the Secretariat of Energy and the Ministry of Sustainable Development and Environment. Task 5. In order to ensure that the potential for problems between power stations and neighbors is minimized, it is essential that development in areas surrounding stations is planned and controlled. Potential for improvements in the planning and enforcement system were identified by Phase I of the study. The Consultant will therefore undertake a review of planning legislation and enforcement as it relates to the zoning of industrial, commercial and residential development. The Consultant should examine the ways in which this legislation is linked to specific requirements for developers to consider environmental issues and controls (noise etc.) regardless of whether full environmental assessments are required on the basis of the study the Consultant will suggest appropriate changes in legislation, policy and/or institutional arrangements. Task 6. The Consultant will undertake environmental noise surveys at the Guaracachi, Valie Hermoso, Aranjuez and (subject to operational status) Villa Abaroa plants. The surveys should evaluate the significance of noise levels with respect to nearby residents and recommend suitable remedial measures if appropriate. Task 7. Concerns were raised during Phase I of the project with respect to soil and groundwater contamination caused by leakage and spillage of diesel fuel and lubricating oils at several plants. The Consultant will therefore evaluate the nature and extent of soil and groundwater contamination at the Trinidad, Villa Abaroa and Guaracachi plants and recommend appropriate short term and, if necessary, long term remedial measures for the identified contamination Task 8. Phase I of the project identified the presence of likely asbestos containing materials at several plants. The Consultant will therefore under separate private contracts assist private utilities to undertaking asbestos surveys, including sampling and analysis, at the Trinidad, Aranjuez and Villa Abaroa plants in order to confirm the presence, extent and condition of asbestos. Survey findings as well as an asbestos management plan describing the recommended measures for managing each identified asbestos-containing material should be presented along with cost estimates. Task 9. The Consultant will undertake a program of environmental awareness and audit training for ENDE plant management. LOCATION: This project will be undertaken in Bolivia.

doc.abstracts: The Power Sector Reform Project aims to assist the Government of Bolivia (GOB) complete the reform programs and ensure their sustainability by: 1) implementing the reforms mandated by the Capitalization and Electricity Laws including refining the regulations of the applicable legal framework; 2) carrying out key transition activities that would ensure the long-term sustainability of the reforms; 3) completing the restructuring of sector assets and corporatizing the smaller utilities of the Isolated Systems; and 4) completing the privatization of Empresa Nacional de Electricidad - Transmission (ENDE-T) and the remaining GOB-owned power sector assets. The project comprises four components: 1) operations of the Power Sector Reform and Capitalization Technical Group (TG) and establishment of the regulatory system; 2) reform transition requirements, including pricing studies, carrying out of the studies, carrying out of the last phase of the environmental assessment, institutional strengthening, and studies to design a strategy for sustainable energy development of rural areas and to enable the GOB to carry out the strategy; 3) restructuring of the GOB-owned utilities; and 4) capitalization and privatization.
